â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : IDN wildcard match may lead to Improper Cerificate Validation 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`. 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Severity        : LOW

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : more POST-after-PUT confusion 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : IDN wildcard match may lead to Improper Cerificate Validation 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`. 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Severity        : LOW

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : more POST-after-PUT confusion 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account. 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Severity        : LOW 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ CweIDs           â”€ [0]: CWE-74

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : OutOfMemoryError for large multipart without filename in Eclipse Jetty 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Jetty is a java based web server and servlet engine. In affected versions servlets with multipart
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   support (e.g. annotated with `@MultipartConfig`) that call `HttpServletRequest.getParameter()` or
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   `HttpServletRequest.getParts()` may cause `OutOfMemoryError` when the client sends a multipart request with
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   a part that has a name but no filename and very large content. This happens even with the default settings
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   of `fileSizeThreshold=0` which should stream the whole part content to disk. An attacker client may send a
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   large multipart request and cause the server to throw `OutOfMemoryError`. However, the server may be able to
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    recover after the `OutOfMemoryError` and continue its service -- although it may take some time. This issue
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    has been patched in versions 9.4.51, 10.0.14, and 11.0.14. Users are advised to upgrade. Users unable to
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   upgrade may set the multipart parameter `maxRequestSize` which must be set to a non-negative value, so the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   whole multipart content is limited (although still read into memory). 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Severity        : MEDIUM

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : Eclipse Jetty's cookie parsing of quoted values can exfiltrate values from other cookies 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Jetty is a java based web server and servlet engine. Nonstandard cookie parsing in Jetty may allow an
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   attacker to smuggle cookies within other cookies, or otherwise perform unintended behavior by tampering with
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    the cookie parsing mechanism. If Jetty sees a cookie VALUE that starts with `"` (double quote), it will
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   continue to read the cookie string until it sees a closing quote -- even if a semicolon is encountered. So,
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   a cookie header such as: `DISPLAY_LANGUAGE="b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d"` will be parsed as one cookie, with the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    name DISPLAY_LANGUAGE and a value of b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d instead of 3 separate cookies. This has
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   security implications because if, say, JSESSIONID is an HttpOnly cookie, and the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE cookie
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   value is rendered on the page, an attacker can smuggle the JSESSIONID cookie into the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   cookie and thereby exfiltrate it. This is significant when an intermediary is enacting some policy based on
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   cookies, so a smuggled cookie can bypass that policy yet still be seen by the Jetty server or its logging
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   system. This issue has been addressed in versions 9.4.51, 10.0.14, 11.0.14, and 12.0.0.beta0 and users are
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   advised to upgrade. There are no known workarounds for this issue. 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Severity        : MEDIUM

â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   `HttpServletRequest.getParts()` may cause `OutOfMemoryError` when the client sends a multipart request with
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   a part that has a name but no filename and very large content. This happens even with the default settings
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   of `fileSizeThreshold=0` which should stream the whole part content to disk. An attacker client may send a
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   large multipart request and cause the server to throw `OutOfMemoryError`. However, the server may be able to
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    recover after the `OutOfMemoryError` and continue its service -- although it may take some time. This issue
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    has been patched in versions 9.4.51, 10.0.14, and 11.0.14. Users are advised to upgrade. Users unable to
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   upgrade may set the multipart parameter `maxRequestSize` which must be set to a non-negative value, so the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   whole multipart content is limited (although still read into memory).

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : Eclipse Jetty's cookie parsing of quoted values can exfiltrate values from other cookies 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Jetty is a java based web server and servlet engine. Nonstandard cookie parsing in Jetty may allow an
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   attacker to smuggle cookies within other cookies, or otherwise perform unintended behavior by tampering with
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    the cookie parsing mechanism. If Jetty sees a cookie VALUE that starts with `"` (double quote), it will
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   continue to read the cookie string until it sees a closing quote -- even if a semicolon is encountered. So,
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   a cookie header such as: `DISPLAY_LANGUAGE="b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d"` will be parsed as one cookie, with the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    name DISPLAY_LANGUAGE and a value of b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d instead of 3 separate cookies. This has
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   security implications because if, say, JSESSIONID is an HttpOnly cookie, and the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE cookie
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   value is rendered on the page, an attacker can smuggle the JSESSIONID cookie into the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   cookie and thereby exfiltrate it. This is significant when an intermediary is enacting some policy based on
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   cookies, so a smuggled cookie can bypass that policy yet still be seen by the Jetty server or its logging
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   system. This issue has been addressed in versions 9.4.51, 10.0.14, 11.0.14, and 12.0.0.beta0 and users are
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   advised to upgrade. There are no known workarounds for this issue.

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : OutOfMemoryError for large multipart without filename in Eclipse Jetty 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Jetty is a java based web server and servlet engine. In affected versions servlets with multipart

â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   of `fileSizeThreshold=0` which should stream the whole part content to disk. An attacker client may send a

â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    recover after the `OutOfMemoryError` and continue its service -- although it may take some time. This issue

â”‚                              â”œ Title           : Eclipse Jetty's cookie parsing of quoted values can exfiltrate values from other cookies 
â”‚                              â”œ Description     : Jetty is a java based web server and servlet engine. Nonstandard cookie parsing in Jetty may allow an
â”‚                              â”‚                   attacker to smuggle cookies within other cookies, or otherwise perform unintended behavior by tampering with
â”‚                              â”‚                    the cookie parsing mechanism. If Jetty sees a cookie VALUE that starts with `"` (double quote), it will
â”‚                              â”‚                   continue to read the cookie string until it sees a closing quote -- even if a semicolon is encountered. So,
â”‚                              â”‚                   a cookie header such as: `DISPLAY_LANGUAGE="b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d"` will be parsed as one cookie, with the
â”‚                              â”‚                    name DISPLAY_LANGUAGE and a value of b; JSESSIONID=1337; c=d instead of 3 separate cookies. This has
â”‚                              â”‚                   security implications because if, say, JSESSIONID is an HttpOnly cookie, and the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE cookie
â”‚                              â”‚                   value is rendered on the page, an attacker can smuggle the JSESSIONID cookie into the DISPLAY_LANGUAGE
â”‚                              â”‚                   cookie and thereby exfiltrate it. This is significant when an intermediary is enacting some policy based on
â”‚                              â”‚                   cookies, so a smuggled cookie can bypass that policy yet still be seen by the Jetty server or its logging
â”‚                              â”‚                   system. This issue has been addressed in versions 9.4.51, 10.0.14, 11.0.14, and 12.0.0.beta0 and users are
â”‚                              â”‚                   advised to upgrade. There are no known workarounds for this issue. 
â”‚                              â”œ Severity        : MEDIUM

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : Arbitrary Code Execution in handlebars 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : Versions of `handlebars` prior to 3.0.8 or 4.5.2 are vulnerable to Arbitrary Code Execution. The
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   package's lookup helper fails to properly validate templates, allowing attackers to submit templates that
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   execute arbitrary JavaScript in the system. It can be used to run arbitrary code in a server processing
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Handlebars templates or on a victim's browser (effectively serving as Cross-Site Scripting).
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   The following template can be used to demonstrate the vulnerability:  
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   ```{{#with "constructor"}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   	{{#with split as |a|}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   		{{pop (push "alert('Vulnerable Handlebars JS');")}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   		{{#with (concat (lookup join (slice 0 1)))}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   			{{#each (slice 2 3)}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   				{{#with (apply 0 a)}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   					{{.}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   				{{/with}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   			{{/each}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   		{{/with}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   	{{/with}}
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   {{/with}}```
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   ## Recommendation
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚

â”‚                              â”œ PkgName         : github.com/lestrrat-go/jwx 
â”‚                              â”œ InstalledVersion: v1.2.25 
â”‚                              â”œ FixedVersion    : 1.2.26

â”‚                              â”‚                  â•° DiffID: sha256:3a7515850641a31bbda0aa948fa5653969765da301ffc6841349804ecbb82ade 
â”‚                              â”œ SeveritySource  : ghsa 
â”‚                              â”œ PrimaryURL      : https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rm8v-mxj3-5rmq 
â”‚                              â”œ DataSource       â•­ ID  : ghsa 
â”‚                              â”‚                  â”œ Name: GitHub Security Advisory Go 
â”‚                              â”‚                  â•° URL : https://github.com/advisories?query=type%3Areviewed+ecosystem%3Ago 
â”‚                              â”œ Title           : github.com/lestrrat-go/jwx vulnerable to Potential Padding Oracle Attack 
â”‚                              â”œ Description     : ### Summary
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   Decrypting AES-CBC encrypted JWE has Potential Padding Oracle Attack Vulnerability.
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   ### Details
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   On [v2.0.10](https://github.com/lestrrat-go/jwx/releases/tag/v2.0.10), decrypting AES-CBC encrypted JWE may
â”‚                              â”‚                   return an error "failed to generate plaintext from decrypted blocks: invalid padding":
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   https://github.com/lestrrat-go/jwx/blob/8840ffd4afc5839f591ff0e9ba9034af52b1643e/jwe/internal/aescbc/aescbc.
â”‚                              â”‚                   go#L210-L213
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   Reporting padding error causes [Padding Oracle Attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Padding_oracle_attack)
â”‚                              â”‚                   Vulnerability.
â”‚                              â”‚                   RFC 7516 JSON Web Encryption (JWE) says that we **MUST NOT** do this.
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   > 11.5.  Timing Attacks
â”‚                              â”‚                   > To mitigate the attacks described in RFC 3218 [RFC3218], the
â”‚                              â”‚                   > recipient MUST NOT distinguish between format, padding, and length
â”‚                              â”‚                   > errors of encrypted keys.  It is strongly recommended, in the event
â”‚                              â”‚                   > of receiving an improperly formatted key, that the recipient
â”‚                              â”‚                   > substitute a randomly generated CEK and proceed to the next step, to
â”‚                              â”‚                   > mitigate timing attacks.
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   In addition, the time to remove padding depends on the length of the padding.
â”‚                              â”‚                   It may leak the length of the padding by Timing Attacks.
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   https://github.com/lestrrat-go/jwx/blob/796b2a9101cf7e7cb66455e4d97f3c158ee10904/jwe/internal/aescbc/aescbc.
â”‚                              â”‚                   go#L33-L66
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   To mitigate Timing Attacks, it MUST be done in constant time.
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   ### Impact
â”‚                              â”‚                   
â”‚                              â”‚                   The authentication tag is verified, so it is not an immediate attack.
â”‚                              â”‚                    
â”‚                              â”œ Severity        : MEDIUM
